title._content: Spanische Romanzen (creators Heinrich Heine and Hugo Steiner-Prag)

description._content: Description: Engraving by Hugo Steiner-Prag for Heinrich Heine’s romantic poem “Almansor” published in a limited edition of Heine’s work “ Spanische Romanzen” (1921). In the poem the baptized Muslim protagonist Almansor expresses his resentment about Cordova's famous desecrated mosque, now a cathedral, and dreams of seeing it crash vengefully down upon the Spanish congregants below. The poem is closely related to Heine’s tragedy "Almansor" which was published in the 1820s. The tragedy is placed in Spain when Christians forced Muslims to convert. As one Muslim character reports in horror of a Koran being burned in the marketplace, another Muslim makes the immortal quote, "That was but a prelude; where they burn books, they will ultimately burn people as well” Heine was referring to the cruelties of the Spanish Inquisition, but he also intended his audience to draw a more modern parallel, with the exhibitionist book-burning and xenophobia of many German "Romantics."
